article.para: Authorize.Net enables you to process encrypted payments using a mobile device, a kiosk, or point-of-sale system. Encryption increases security by encrypting payment data as it is being read by the card reader. Authorize.Net uses 3DES for encryption.
article.subtitle: Components
article.para: There are three components involved in an encrypted payment:

listitem.para: The card reader used to encrypt the data. The reader must have an Authorize.Net encryption key in order to work with Authorize.Net systems. Sandbox and production environments use different encryption keys, so you must use different card readers for matching environments. Test thoroughly in the sandbox environment before moving to the production environment.
The reader’s SDK, which communicates between the reader and the payment application. The SDK is provided by the manufacturer.
The payment app, which is created by Authorize.Net and integrated with the reader’s SDK to provide shopping and payment functions with the card reader.

article.subtitle: Authentication
article.para: There are two authentication methods depending on the type of device that you are using, shown below.

When you use a mobile device to process encrypted payments, you must use your user login ID, password, and device ID for authentication. After you are logged in, subsequent transactions use login ID, session token, and device ID for authentication.
Note: For security purposes, never store your API login and transaction key on a mobile device.
When using a server device like a POS kiosk, securely store and use the API login ID and transaction key for authentication.
Note: The transaction key should be stored on and retrieved from the service device.
article.subtitle: Obtaining an Encrypted Card Reader
article.para: To process encrypted payments with Authorize.Net, you must use a card reader with an approved key. You can acquire an approved reader at the Authorize.Net POS Portal.
